Novel medium entropy perovskite oxide Sr(FeCoNiMo)1/4O3− δ for zinc-air battery cathode Kaixin Li Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization a b Juntao Gao Writing – review & editing Supervision a b Xu Han Writing – review & editing Supervision a b Qi Shao Writing – review & editing Supervision a b Zhe Lü Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Funding acquisition a b ⁎ a School of Physics, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, Heilongjiang, China School of Physics Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin Heilongjiang 150001 China School of Physics, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, Heilongjiang, China b Heilongjiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Quantum Functional Materials and Sensor Components, Harbin 150001, Heilongjiang, China Heilongjiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Quantum Functional Materials and Sensor Components Harbin Heilongjiang 150001 China Heilongjiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Quantum Functional Materials and Sensor Components, Harbin 150001, Heilongjiang, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Conformational entropy doping strategies effectively modulate the electronic structure and oxygen vacancy concentration of perovskite oxides thereby driving the OER process from an AEM mechanism to a more efficient LOM pathway. It is widely recognized that the development of ZABs is impeded by the kinetic bottleneck of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The application of conformational entropy strategy to oxides often involves introducing multiple elements with different properties, thereby providing outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity for OER/ORR. Nevertheless, the possible underlying catalytic pathways and potential interactions between various components are still poorly understood. This paper presents an excellent medium-entropy perovskite oxide, Sr(FeCoNiMo)1/4O3− δ (lower overpotential of 301 mV at 10 mA cm−2). Zinc-air batteries employing it as a cathode catalyst demonstrate excellent round-trip efficiency (62%). By combining theoretical calculation with experiments, we aim to establish the link between the electronic structure of perovskite oxides with different elemental compositions and their OER mechanism. Research reveals that the conformational entropy strategy can simultaneously shift the O 2p-band center and metal d-band center of perovskite oxide towards the vicinity of the Fermi energy level, thereby triggering a more favorable lattice oxygen-participated mechanism (LOM) during the OER process. The outcomes of this work provide crucial insights into the role of conformational entropy strategies in oxygen catalysis and offer potential avenues for constructing efficient and stable electrocatalysts. Keywords Sr(FeCoNiMo)1/4O3− δ Bifunctional catalyst Medium entropy LOM Rechargeable zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction The intricate global landscape and growing environmental consciousness are driving the quest for clean and sustainable energy storage and conversion technologies, aiming to decrease reliance on fossil fuels [1]. Given their exceptional reversibility, stability, and high theoretical energy density, zinc-air batteries (ZABs) stand out among a variety of metal-air batteries [2–5]. However, the energy conversion efficiency of ZABs is constrained by the activity and stability of the bifunctional catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [6]. Until now, noble metal Ru-based and Pt-based materials remain the performance benchmarks for OER or ORR. Nevertheless, their single-aspect catalytic activity, scarcity, and poor stability impede their broader applications [7]. Therefore, it is imperative to research efficient, durable, and cost-effective catalysts to take the place of noble metal-based materials [8,9]. Transition metal-based oxides, including spinel oxides, perovskite oxides, monometallic oxides, etc., have been widely studied owing to their low price and abundant reserves [10,11]. Perovskite oxides have attracted significant attention due to their excellent stability under alkaline conditions, acceptable catalytic activity, and cost advantages. Typically, the A-site in the perovskite oxide with the molecular formula ABO3 is occupied by alkaline earth or rare earth metal elements, which have relatively larger ionic radii, while the B-site is filled by transition metal elements that act as the active sites for catalytic reactions [12,13]. Considering the relatively poor catalytic activity of single-component perovskite oxides, their OER/ORR activity can be modulated through approaches such as ion doping, defect engineering, morphology control, and composite formation with other materials [14–17]. For example, the OER activity of materials such as SrCo0.8Fe0.1Nb0.1O3− δ [18], BaCo0.4Fe0.4Y0.1Zr0.1O3− δ [19],Pr0.5Ba0.3Ca0.2CoO3− δ [20], Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3− δ -F [21], and Sr0.95Ce0.05Fe0.9Ni0.1O3− δ [22], which are designed through A/B/O site ion doping, can surpass that of RuO2. Materials such as La0.8Y0.2MnO3 [23], CaMnO3-RGO [24], and La0.8Sr0.2Mn0.95Sc0.025P0.025O3− δ [25] prepared through morphology modulation and compositing with carbon materials, exhibit properties comparable to Pt/C in terms of ORR. In addition, research has shown that MOOH (M = Ni, Fe, and Co) formed on the surface of perovskite oxides plays a critical role in the OER reaction [26–29]. Zhang et al. reported that partial substitution of Ce at the A-site facilitated the surface reconstruction of the B-site cation in La0.9Ce0.1NiO3, leading to the formation of highly catalytically active NiOOH [30]. He and colleagues reported that surface F-ion doping effectively reduced the oxygen vacancy formation energy of LaNi0.75Fe0.25O3, thereby promoting the formation of hydroxide/perovskite heterostructures [31]. Materials such as PrBa0.5Sr0.5Co2− x Fe x O5+ δ [32], LaCo0.75Fe0.25O3 [33], and LaNi0.85Mg0.15O3 [34], prepared through techniques like hydrothermal method, template method, and electrospinning, display a larger specific surface area compared to those prepared by the traditional sol-gel method, thereby exhibiting stronger bifunctional OER/ORR activity. Previous studies suggest that changing the reaction pathway of the OER can help perovskite oxides achieve higher reaction activity [35,36]. Chen et al. revealed that the OER reaction pathway of Rp-type perovskite (La1− x Sr x )2CoO4− δ could be changed from adsorbate evolution mechanism to lattice oxygen-participated mechanism by altering the A-site Sr ion ratio [37]. Shao et al. provided direct evidence for the participation of lattice oxygen in O2 generation in SrCoO3− δ using 18O isotope technology [38]. Xi et al. found that the concentration of oxygen vacancies could be manipulated by varying the ball milling duration for La x Sr1− x CoO3− δ , which allowed for a flexible transition between the lattice oxygen-participated mechanism (LOM) and adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) path [39]. Until to now, despite the increasingly deep research on perovskites, there is still an urgent need to adopt traditional production methods for their large-scale production applications. Recently, the application of conformational entropy modulation to perovskite oxides has been an effective strategy for designing materials with both high catalytic activity and enhanced stability [40]. The term high entropy was first coined primarily from alloys. Its core characteristics mainly include sluggish diffusion, high entropy effect, cocktail effect, and lattice distortion. The entropy value of the perovskite oxide will be calculated according to the following equation [41,42]. (1) Δ S m i x = - R ∑ a = 1 n x a ln x a A - site + ∑ b = 1 n x b ln x b B - site + 3 ∑ c = 1 n x c ln x c O - site where x a , x b , and x c denote the molar fractions of the elements located at the A, B, and O positions, respectively, R is the gas constant. The entropy value can be divided into < 1R, 1R to 1.5R, and > 1.5R, corresponding respectively to low-entropy, medium-entropy, and high-entropy oxides [43]. Lv et al. demonstrated that doping rare earths at the A-site with high entropy facilitates the suppression of Sr polarization, thus improving the stability of perovskite in terms of resistance to Cr poisoning [41]. Wang et al. reported that the overpotential of high-entropy-doped perovskite fluoride at the B-site is 310 mV (1 M KOH solution) under a current density of 10 mA cm− 2 [44]. He et al. reported that medium-entropy-doped Sr2(Fe1.0Ti0.25Cr0.25Mn0.25Mo0.25)O6− δ demonstrates excellent catalytic activity and stability when applied in solid oxide electrolysis cells [45]. Sun et al. reported that the OER path of La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.2Mn0.2Ni0.2Mg0.2O3 changes into the LOM mechanism with increased entropy [46]. Nevertheless, the possible underlying catalytic pathways and potential interactions between various components are still poorly understood. Hence, it is crucial to examine the influence of different component elements in the configurational entropy strategy on the electronic structure of perovskite oxides and their role in instigating the LOM/AEM mechanisms. Here, we report a medium entropy-doped Sr(FeCoNiMo)1/4O3− δ (SFCNM, ΔS mix = 1.4R) perovskite oxide, where the B site is equally occupied by Ni, Fe, Mo, and Co. The corresponding base sample was Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6− δ (SFM, ΔS mix = 0.56R), a conventional electrocatalyst broadly utilized in numerous electrocatalytic applications. Additionally, ternary-doped Sr(FeCoMo)1/3O3− δ (SFCM, ΔS mix = 1.1R) and Sr(FeNiMo)1/3O3− δ (SFNM, ΔS mix = 1.1R) are examined further for comparison. The catalytic activity of the as-prepared perovskite oxides towards both OER and ORR was assessed in an alkaline environment using a three-electrode system. By combining density functional theory (DFT) with experiments, we delve deeply into the effects of the conformational entropy strategy on their crystal structures, oxygen defects, electronic structures, and surface adsorption and desorption capabilities. The role of different B-site elements in the conformational entropy strategy was determined by investigating the changes in the electronic structure of perovskites with varying compositions and their OER pathways. The stability and bi-functionality activity of SFCNM under operating conditions were further evaluated through homemade ZABs. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structure characterizations The phase structures and compositions of the SFM, SFCM, SFNM, and SFCNM were analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns and corresponding refinement results (Fig. 1 a–c and Fig. S1). The as-prepared perovskite oxides with different degrees of entropy values all exhibit well-crystalline cubic phases (Fm − 3 m) [47–49]. Except for SFCM, which displayed traces of the SrMoO4 impurity phase, none of the materials exhibited a secondary phase in the XRD plots. Further Evidence of the crystal structure of SFCNM is provided by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images and corresponding FFT patterns, as shown in Fig. 1 (e–g). The plane spacings of 1.57 and 2.73 Å align well with the (422) and (220) crystal planes in the XRD plots of SFCNM, respectively. Furthermore, a homogeneous distribution of Sr, Fe, Co, Ni, Mo, and O in SFCNM is evidenced by scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) maps, as shown in Fig. 1(h). The impact of conformational entropy doping on the crystal structure of perovskites was further characterized by Raman, as shown in Fig. S2. According to previous studies, the peak near 820 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration of the Mo–O bond [50,51]. In comparison with other perovskite oxides, SFCNM exhibits an additional characteristic peak of about 760 cm−1. This is primarily attributed to the enhanced lattice distortion and structural disorder associated with increasing conformational entropy. Incorporating elements with different ion radii into the lattice of SFCNM leads to a reduction in its symmetry and the presence of lattice distortion. In such cases, the crystal often contains more defects. Crystals containing impurities and defects will have a phonon spectrum different from that of the intact lattice due to their broken translational symmetry, resulting in localized vibrational modes centered on the impurities and defects [52]. This lattice distortion will result in an asymmetric distribution of charge densities, which to a certain extent, facilitates the desorption and adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates during the catalytic reaction, thereby accelerating the reaction kinetics. The particle size and morphology of the as-prepared samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As shown in Fig. 1(d) and Fig. S3, the samples exhibited an irregular shape, and noticeable agglomeration occurred due to the preparation technique and ball milling process. The Scherrer equation was utilized to further analyze the XRD plots of the as-prepared samples. The average particle sizes of SFM, SFCM, SFNM, and SFCNM were determined to be 34, 24, 24, and 19 nm, respectively. In comparison to SFM, the phase formation temperature of medium entropy perovskite SFCNM was reduced from 1100 to 1000 °C. This reduction could potentially prevent excessive particle size expansion during the high-temperature roasting process. The reduction in particle size is undoubtedly beneficial for increasing the number of active sites in OER/ORR processes. Given that catalytic reactions primarily take place on the surface of catalysts, we further investigated the impact of conformational entropy doping on the surface composition and adsorption/desorption properties of the perovskite samples. Fig. 2 (a) shows the O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) of SFCNM and SFM within the temperature range of 25–800 °C. The peak observed below approximately 500 °C corresponds to the chemisorption of surface oxygen [53,54]. The peaks in the region above 500 °C correspond to the release of lattice oxygen, which is caused by the thermal reduction of B-site cations at high temperatures. The lower temperature of the desorption peak center and the larger peak area suggest an enhanced surface oxygen exchange capacity for SFCNM. This undoubtedly facilitates its ORR/OER catalytic activity. The effect of the conformational entropy approach on the surface composition of SFCNM was investigated by utilizing X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS spectra of Sr 3d (Fig. S4b) were deconvoluted into Sr-surface and Sr-lattice [47]. The Sr-surface is mainly attributed to catalytically inert phases such as SrO and Sr(OH)2 which are segregated on the surface of perovskite oxides. Meanwhile, the Sr-surface tends to dissolve more readily in the electrolyte during OER processes, potentially leading to surface defects or even structural collapse. Compared to SFM (54.8%), the Sr-surface content of SFCNM is reduced to 40.1%, which is undoubtedly beneficial for its catalytic activity and stability. Referring to the results reported in the literature, it is evident that the XPS pattern of Mo 3d can be fitted to Mo5+ (232.2 eV for 3d 5/2) and Mo6+ (232.2 eV for 3d 5/2). Moreover, the Mo5+/Mo6+ ratios of SFCNM and SFM are essentially constant, suggesting that the valence state of the Mo ions remains relatively stable. The XPS patterns of Fe 2p, Co 2p, and Ni 2p can be fitted to both divalent and trivalent valence states(Fig. S4d–f). By analyzing the XPS spectra and fitting the areas corresponding to ions with different valence states, it is determined that the B-site cation valence states of SFM and SFCNM are 3.94 + and 3.82+, respectively. A higher proportion of oxygen vacancies in SFCNM can be derived from the principle of charge conservation. Generally, surface oxygen vacancies play a pivotal role in catalytic processes, as they are intimately associated with the formation of oxygen-containing intermediates in the LOM mechanism. The O 1s spectrum in Fig. 2(b) was deconvoluted into four parts including water/molecular carbonates (H2O/CO3 2−), surface adsorbed oxygen/hydroxyl groups (O2/OH−), highly oxidative oxygen (O2 2−/O−), and lattice oxygen species (O2−) to understand its oxygen chemical environment [55,56]. In comparison to SFM (12%), the fraction of O2 2−/O− in SFCNM rises to 18%, suggesting a higher concentration of surface oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, we used DFT to further assess the cause of the greater oxygen vacancies in SFCNM. The theoretical models for different catalysts are shown in Fig. S5. Fig. 2(c,d) and Fig. S6 display Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) calculations for SFCNM and SFM, which is an effective tool for evaluating how conformational entropy doping affects the nature of the B–O (B = Fe, Co, Ni, and Mo) bonds and the formation of oxygen defects. The crystal structure diagram in Fig. S6 represents the structure of all the samples prepared. The −COHP value is determined by the difference between the integrals across the energy levels of the bonding and antibonding states below the Fermi energy level. It is evident that more anti-bonding state (below the Fermi energy level) components exist in Fe–O bonds in comparison to Mo–O bonds both in SFM and SFCNM, suggesting that Fe–O bond strength is lower than that of Mo–O bonds. Additionally, Mo–O–Co and Mo–O–Ni bonds in SFCNM exhibit a similar behaviour. The computed −COHP values for Mo–O and B–O (B = Ni, Fe, and Co) for SFCNM and SFM are near to 3 and 1, respectively, indicating that Mo–O bonding is a major factor restricting the formation of oxygen vacancies in perovskite. As shown in Fig. 2(c, d) and Fig. S6, the strength of the Ni–O, and Co–O bonds in SFCNM is obviously reduced with respect to the Fe–O bonds in SFM, which is undoubtedly conducive to promoting the formation of oxygen vacancies. In addition, to more intuitively illustrate the effect of conformational entropy on oxygen vacancies in SFCNM, the formation energies of oxygen vacancies at different positions were calculated. One of the 24 oxygen atoms in a 2*2*2 lattice was removed to simulate the creation of oxygen vacancies. As shown in Fig. 2(e), the oxygen vacancies formation energies of the above samples follow the order of Mo–VO–Fe (SFM, 3.05 eV) > Mo–VO–Fe (SFCNM, 2.87 eV) > Mo–VO–Co (SFM, 2.69 eV) > Fe–VO–Fe (SFM, 2.62 eV) > Mo–VO–Ni (SFCNM, 2.56 eV) > Co–VO–Fe (SFCNM, 1.67 eV) > Co–VO–Ni (SFCNM, 1.64 eV) > Ni–VO–Fe (SFCNM, 1.58 eV). The aforementioned findings indicate that the formation of oxygen vacancies is significantly promoted through conformational entropy doping. The slightly raised oxygen vacancies not only contribute to the optimization of its crystal structures but also have the potential to serve as potential reactive active sites in the OER processes thereby reducing its energy barriers. 2.2 Electrocatalytic performance The catalytic activity of the as-prepared perovskite oxides towards both OER and ORR was assessed in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution using a three-electrode system. The linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) curves for the performance measurements of ORR/OER were obtained at a speed of 1600 r min−1 using the rotating disk electrode (RDE). RuO2 and the traditional perovskite oxide Ba0.5Sr0.5Fe0.2Co0.8O3− δ (BSCF) were employed for performance comparison. Compared to SFM (η 10 = 531 mV), SFCM (η 10 = 386 mV), and SFNM (η 10 = 360 mV), SFCNM exhibits the lowest overpotential (η 10 = 301 mV) at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3 a, b). This demonstrates the significance of medium entropy doping in enhancing OER performance. The overpotentials of SFCNM are reduced by 56 and 42 mV respectively, when compared to BSCF and RuO2, thereby affirming its superior OER performance. Fig. 3(c) illustrates that SFCNM (42.3 mV dec−1) also exhibits a much lower Tafel slope in comparison with SFM (76.5 mV dec−1), SFCM (62.1 mV dec−1), and SFNM (55.6 mV dec−1). The significantly lower Tafel slope may be attributed to a change in the rate-limiting step of the OER process. The lowest polarisation resistance of SFCNM suggests a quicker charge transfer during OER, according to a comparison of the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plots of several catalysts recorded at 1.55 V vs. RHE (Fig. 3d). The CV curves in the non-Faraday region at various sweep speeds were investigated to determine the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) and double-layer capacitance (C dl) to further examine its excellent OER performance (Fig. S7). As shown in Fig. 3(e), the C dl of perovskite catalyst follows the order of SFM (0.55 mF cm−2) < SFNM (0.73 mF cm−2) < SFCM (2.06 mF cm−2) < SFCNM (2.23 mF cm−2). This suggests that the doping of Co is more favorable for the increase of electrochemically active sites as compared to Ni. More electrochemically active sites from the Co element are retained by the medium entropy doped SFCNM, which is advantageous for its OER performance. As depicted in Fig. 3(f), SFCNM exhibits superior OER performance in the ECSA-normalized LSV curves, suggesting that it possesses maximum intrinsic activity. Furthermore, the OER catalytic activity of SFCNM exceeds that of most of the transition metal-based perovskites such as Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, etc. reported in the literature (Fig. 3g). An exceptional perovskite catalyst must possess not only high catalytic activity but also long-term operational stability. Hence, we examined the OER stability of SFCNM through chronopotentiometry and CV cycling tests. To prevent the impact of sample dropout during rotating disc electrode work, we utilized nickel foam as a load of peroxide samples to verify its stability. As shown in Fig. S8, the gap between the OER performance of SFCNM using RDE and nickel foam as loading in KOH solution is small. The catalytic activity of SFCNM showed negligible degradation after enduring 1000 cycles and 50 h of long-term testing at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, as depicted in Fig. S9. In-situ Raman plots following CV testing at different circles revealed the absence of a second phase on the surface of SFCNM, confirming its relative stability (Fig. S10). This further demonstrates that the OER active site in SFCNM is the perovskite itself, rather than the surface-reconstructed MOOH (M = Fe, Co, and Ni) as previously reported in the literature. The surface and crystal structures of SFCNM were further analyzed by XPS and XRD after the 50 h stability test. As depicted in Fig. S11, the O 1s spectra indicate that only surface-adsorbed oxygen persists after the OER testing. This suggests a reduction in surface crystallinity after the OER testing. The XRD plots reveal that SFCNM maintains its perovskite structure following long-term testing, with the diminished peak intensity primarily attributable to a reduction in surface crystallinity (Fig. S12). The aforementioned results demonstrate the exceptional stability of SFCNM in long-term OER tests. The ORR catalytic activity of the above perovskite samples was recorded under the same conditions. As depicted in Fig. 4 (a), The most positive half-wave potential (E j=1/2), as well as the onset potential of SFCNM relative to SFM, SFCM, and SFNM, indicate its excellent ORR catalytic activity. In comparison to the well-known material BSCF (E j=1/2 = 0.6 V vs. RHE), SFCNM (E j=1/2 = 0.64 V vs. RHE) also demonstrates a 40 mV increase in half-wave potential. Fig. S13 presents the LSV curves for a series of perovskite samples at various rotational speed intervals. The electron transfer numbers of SFCNM at 0.45, 0.4, 0.35, and 0.3 V vs. RHE calculated by the Koutecky-Levich equation are 3.25, 3.3, 3.44, and 3.6, respectively (Fig. 4b). The electron transfer numbers for several other catalyst materials were shown in Fig. S14. This means that its ORR process is close to the more favorable four-electron process. The ΔE defined as ΔE = E j=10 mA cm−2 − E j=1/2 is typically applied to describe the ORR/OER bifunctional catalytic activity of a catalyst material, where a smaller ΔE implies a superior performance. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the ΔE of the as-prepared samples follows the order of SFCNM (0.891 V) < SFCM (1.01 V) < SFNM (1.02 V) < SFM (1.23 V), which implies an optimal bifunctional catalytic activity of SFCNM. Additionally, the ΔE of SFCNM is smaller than that of most perovskite oxides reported in the literature, signifying its exceptional bifunctional catalytic activity. 2.3 Research on OER pathways The widely accepted mechanisms for the OER process in perovskite oxides are primarily the AEM and LOM mechanisms. Previous research suggests that the more readily formed oxygen vacancies in SFCNM may regulate its reaction pathways and rate-limiting steps. Unlike the AEM pathway where the transition metal elements at the B-site function as reactive active sites, the LOM mechanism primarily involves redox reactions occurring at the lattice oxygen sites. This requires the O 2p-band center much closer to the Fermi energy level to facilitate electron transfer between the O orbitals and adsorbates in the reaction. Hence, DS-PAW was employed to further investigate the density of states (DOS) of the SFM, SFNM, SFCM, and SFCNM samples with the aim of comprehending the potential factors contributing to the alterations in catalytic reactions [57]. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the richer electronic state of SFCNM near the Fermi energy level, compared to SFM, suggests a potential increase in its conductivity. As shown in Fig. 5(c), we used the four-probe method to test the conductivity (room temperature) of a series of catalyst samples and obtained the following order: SFCNM (5.9 × 10−2 S cm−1) > SFCM (1.2 × 10−2 S cm−1) > SFNM (6.1 × 10−3 S cm−1) > SFM (6.8 × 10−7 S cm−1). The enhanced conductivity undeniably contributes to the improvement of the bifunctional catalytic activity of SFCNM. As depicted in Fig. 5(b), the distances from the center of the O 2p-band and metal d-band to the Fermi energy level are −2.07 and −1.74 eV, −2.2 and −0.95 eV, −1.85 and −1.24 eV, and −1.45 and −1.24 eV for SFM, SFCM, SFNM, and SFCNM, respectively. For SFCM, the metal d-band center is extremely close to the Fermi energy level, but the oxygen p-band center significantly decreases. In this scenario, the redox electrochemistry of B-site cations is thermodynamically favorable for electron transfer with adsorbed oxygen intermediates. Its OER process will adhere to the traditional AEM approach in this instance. For SFNM, both the metal d-band center and the O 2p-band center evenly shift towards the Fermi energy level, which could potentially activate the more favorable LOM pathway. Benefiting from the cocktail effect, both the O 2p-band center and metal d-band center of SFCNM move closer to the Fermi energy level, and the degree of hybridization between them deepens. In this case, when a certain external voltage is applied, the Fermi energy level penetrates the O 2p orbitals and positions the O 2p energy above the redox potential of O2/H2O. Therefore, this makes the oxidation of lattice oxygen thermodynamically more favorable, thus activating the LOM mechanism. Due to the strong d-d Coulomb interactions among transition metal d-electrons, the d-band splits into an electron-filled lower-Hubbard band (LHB) and an electron-empty upper Hubbard band (UHB) [58,59]. As shown in Fig. S15, we further analyzed the metal partial density of states (pDOS) of a series of perovskite oxides and obtained the LHB and UHB. The LHB of a series of materials is sufficiently low, providing a prerequisite for the activation of the LOM mechanism. We further investigate the reaction mechanisms in the OER process of SFCNM to gain insight into how conformational entropy doping affects the catalytic activity of SFCNMs. Previous studies suggest that the TMA+ cations exhibit substantial binding affinity to the surface O2 2− of perovskite oxides during the LOM process, effectively obstructing the active lattice oxygen sites and hindering oxygen formation [60]. Therefore, introducing TMA+ cations into the OER process can effectively distinguish between the AEM and LOM pathways. As depicted in Fig. 5(d), the loss of OER activity for SFM and SFCM in 0.1 M TMAOH solution is negligible compared to that in the KOH solution. In contrast, the overpotentials of SFNM and SFCNM in the TMAOH solution show a significant increase compared to those in the KOH solution. This indicates that the doping of Ni ions facilitates the OER process to follow the LOM mechanism. The LSV curves of SFCNM recorded in KOH solution within the pH range of 12.5–14 display a clear pH dependence, which equally proves the crucial role of the LOM pathway in its OER process (Fig. S16). DFT calculations were performed to analyze the energy changes of adsorbed oxygen species in SFCNM within both the AEM and LOM mechanisms to provide further insights into the enhanced OER performance. Fig. 6 (a and b) depict the reaction pathways for AEM and LOM, respectively. To ensure objectivity in the analysis, calculations were carried out on seven different sites within the (001) crystal plane of SFM and SFCNM. These sites included Fe1, Fe2, and Mo in the SFM crystal plane, as well as the tops of Fe, Co, Ni, and Mo atoms in the SFCNM crystal plane, as shown in Figs. S17–S19. The energy changes along the LOM path of SFCNM were also further analyzed. The RDS of the Fe1, Fe2, and Mo sites of the SFM all correspond to *O to *OOH processes with energy barriers of 1.3, 2.1, and 2.3 eV, respectively (Fig. 6c and Fig. S19). The theoretical thermodynamic overpotential (η) of Fe, Co, Ni, and Mo for SFCNM calculated based on the AEM path occurring are 0.8, 0.7, 0.6, and 1.3 V respectively, which were significantly lower than those of SFM (Fig. 6g). Moreover, the η of SFCNM based on LOM mechanisms was calculated to be 0.27 V, which is significantly lower than that of 0.6 V for the AEM pathway reaction (Fig. 6d–g). The above demonstrates that the catalytic process of SFCNM is primarily governed by the LOM mechanism. 2.4 Zn-air batteries Considering the outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity displayed by SFCNM, we proceeded to conduct further investigations into its performance using homemade ZABs. The schematic structure of a ZAB as shown in Fig. 7 (a). Fig. 7(b) depicts the open-circuit voltage profile of the cell utilizing SFM and SFCNM as air electrode catalysts. The open circuit voltage of the ZABs using SFCNM as the catalyst is notably higher at 1.43 V in comparison to SFM (1.38 V). In comparison with the charging and discharging polarization curves of SFM, it's apparent that the cell with SFCNM as the catalyst exhibits a lower voltage difference at the same current density (Fig. 7c). According to the data presented in Fig. 7(d), the peak power density of the battery employing SFCNM as the catalyst is observed to be 96.6 mW cm−2 at room temperature, which is 1.3 times higher compared to SFM. Fig. 7(e) shows the EIS plots of ZABs recorded at 1 V (vs. Zn) for different catalysts. The corresponding data were obtained by fitting equivalent circuits to them via Zivew (Table S2). The same electrode spacing and electrolyte allowed SFM and SFCNM as catalysts for ZABs to exhibit similar R S. Compared to SFM (0.88 Ω), the smaller R int of SFCNM (0.71 Ω) is attributed to its superior conductivity. The lower R ct compared to SFM means that SFCNM has a faster charge transfer rate during the ORR process. The ZABs utilizing SFCNM as the catalyst demonstrate higher discharge voltages at various current densities compared to SFM (Fig. 7f). As shown in Fig. 7(g), SFCNM also demonstrates a more stable discharge process and higher specific capacity of 799 mA h g−1 in long-term constant current discharge (10 mA cm−2) compared to SFM (730 mA h g−1). Fig. 7(h) illustrates the performance of reversible ZABs (30 min for charging, 30 min for discharging) utilizing various catalysts at 10 mA cm−2. The initial charge cut-off voltage and discharge cut-off voltage of ZABs using SFCNM as a catalyst are 1.21 and 1.95 V, respectively, demonstrating excellent round-trip efficiency of 62%. The energy efficiency ranks among the highest compared to catalysts previously reported in the literature, as shown in Table S3. Notably, the charge/discharge voltage gap of the ZABs incorporating SFCNM as the catalyst only increased by 0.09 V after 100 cycles (100 h) from the first cycle. In contrast, the catalytic activity of commercial Pt/C rapidly declines in less than 100 h. It demonstrates that SFCNM is a promising catalyst for ZABs with not only excellent bifunctional catalytic activity but also remarkable stability. 3 Conclusions In summary, B-site medium-entropy-doped SFCNM was synthesized as a bifunctional oxygen electrode catalyst for ZABs. SFCNM exhibited excellent bifunctional activity (ΔE = 0.89 V) and the lowest overpotential (301 mV, 10 mA cm−2) in 0.1 M KOH solution. ZABs employing it as a cathode catalyst demonstrate excellent round-trip efficiency (62%). The reduced overpotential of SFCNM primarily originates from the shift between the AEM and LOM mechanisms, as revealed by pH dependence measurements, TMAOH tests, and DFT calculations. Configuration entropy doping reduces the formation energy of oxygen vacancies and promotes the movement of metal d-band centers and O 2p-band centers toward the Fermi level. Which makes the oxidation of lattice oxygen thermodynamically more favorable, thus activating the LOM mechanism. The outcomes of this work provide crucial insights into the role of conformational entropy strategies in oxygen catalysis and offer potential avenues for constructing efficient and stable electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: It is widely recognized that the development of ZABs is impeded by the kinetic bottleneck of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The application of conformational entropy strategy to oxides often involves introducing multiple elements with different properties, thereby providing outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity for OER/ORR. Nevertheless, the possible underlying catalytic pathways and potential interactions between various components are still poorly understood. This paper presents an excellent medium-entropy perovskite oxide, Sr(FeCoNiMo)1/4O3− δ (lower overpotential of 301 mV at 10 mA cm−2). Zinc-air batteries employing it as a cathode catalyst demonstrate excellent round-trip efficiency (62%). By combining theoretical calculation with experiments, we aim to establish the link between the electronic structure of perovskite oxides with different elemental compositions and their OER mechanism. Research reveals that the conformational entropy strategy can simultaneously shift the O 2p-band center and metal d-band center of perovskite oxide towards the vicinity of the Fermi energy level, thereby triggering a more favorable lattice oxygen-participated mechanism (LOM) during the OER process. The outcomes of this work provide crucial insights into the role of conformational entropy strategies in oxygen catalysis and offer potential avenues for constructing efficient and stable electrocatalysts.
